metadata.case_name: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Math

facts.text: Shirur Math is one of eight Maths at Udipi founded by Shri Madhwacharya, presided by Sanyasi or Swami.
Shri Krishna Devara Math at Udipi managed by superiors of eight Maths in turn for two years every sixteen years; Pariyayam festival involves feeding Brahmins.
Petitioner (respondent) installed as Mathadhipati in 1919 as minor, assumed management in 1926; Math heavily in debt, cleared portion by 1930.
In 1931, petitioner took over Shri Krishna Math, incurred debts for Pariyayam.
Financial troubles in 1946 during second Pariyayam due to scarcity; debts mounted to nearly a lakh of rupees.
Hindu Religious Endowments Board under 1927 Act intervened under section 61-A, directed appointment of competent manager.
Action instigated by Lakshminarayana Rao; Sripath Achar appointed agent, Power of Attorney on 24th December 1948.
Agent disregarded Mathadhipati's wishes, did not submit accounts; notice terminating agency served on 26th September 1950.
Agent questioned termination, threatened Board reference.
Petitioner filed suit in Sub-Court South Kanara on 4th October 1950 for accounts, injunction against agent.
Agent filed application to Board on 3rd October 1950 complaining against cancellation.
Board issued notice on 4th October 1950 for inquiry on 24th October; Swami replied on 21st October matter sub-judice.
Board dropped inquiry, initiated suo motu proceedings under section 62 on 6th November 1950 for scheme; notice served by affixture, inquiry 8th December 1950.
Inquiry adjourned to 21st December at counsel's request; application for agent to hand over accounts.
Further adjourned to 10th January 1951 due to counsel illness; no objections filed, inquiry closed.
Written explanation sent 13th January 1951, received 15th.
Notice on 24th January 1951 with draft scheme, objections by 11th February, final order 15th February.
Petition filed in Madras High Court on 12th February 1951 for writ of prohibition.
Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act 1951 came into force 27th August 1951; petitions amended.
High Court judgment 13th December 1951 allowed petition, issued writ of prohibition.
Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate under Article 132(1).

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions of Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act 1951 conflict with Articles 19(1)(f), 25, 26 of Constitution regarding rights of Mathadhipati.
Whether section 76 contribution is a tax beyond state competence or violates Article 27.
Whether Mathadhipati has property rights under Article 19(1)(f); scope of Articles 25, 26 for religious denominations.

petitioner_arguments.text: State Legislature competent under entry 28 List III; Act imposes reasonable restrictions; no violation of fundamental rights.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 28 List III Sch VII; Articles 19(5), 25(2), 26

petitioner_arguments.text: Article 19(1)(f) concerns abstract rights, not concrete property; Article 25 for individuals only; Article 26 limited to essential religious matters.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose; Article 25, 26(b)

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 76 is a fee for services, not tax.

respondent_arguments.text: Act interferes with management by Mathadhipati, violates rights under Articles 19(1)(f), 25, 26; discriminatory under 15; Board biased.
Math is religious denomination of Sivalli Brahmins; rights to manage affairs in matters of religion.

court_reasoning.text: Mathadhipati has proprietary interest blended with office, protected under Article 19(1)(f); restrictions must be reasonable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mahantship combines office and property; beneficial interest appurtenant to duties.

court_reasoning.text: Article 25 protects propagation by Mathadhipati as religious teacher; Article 26 applies to Math as section of Madhwacharya followers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Religious denomination includes sects with common faith; matters of religion include essential rituals.

court_reasoning.text: Section 21 invalid: unrestricted entry interferes with religious practices; sections 30(2), 31, 55, 56 invalid as unreasonable restrictions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot reduce Mathadhipati to servant; secular activities regulable but not spiritual.
Supervision necessary for public endowments; safeguards exist.

court_reasoning.text: Section 76 is fee for services, not tax; within competence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Quid pro quo via services rendered; distinction from tax.

holdings.text: Mathadhipati's rights protected under Articles 19(1)(f), 25, 26; Math is religious denomination.
Sections 21, 30(2), 31, 55(1)(2), 56, 63-69 invalid as violating fundamental rights.
Section 76 contribution is a fee, valid under state competence; does not violate Article 27.

precedents_cited.relevance: Mathadhipati is manager/custodian, not mere trustee.
Shebaiti right combines office and property.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose
precedents_cited.relevance: Article 19(1)(f) on abstract vs concrete rights (not decided).

statutes_cited.name: Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1927
statutes_cited.relevance: Earlier Act; proceedings transitioned to New Act.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned Act; various sections held valid/invalid.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental rights violations challenged; scope interpreted.

outcome.summary: High Court order issuing writ of prohibition upheld on merits (not challenged); on constitutionality, Supreme Court upheld invalidity of sections 21, 30(2), 31, 55, 56, 63-69 but reversed invalidity of other sections including 76; writ stands prohibiting scheme settlement.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ of prohibition continued; certain Act provisions declared ultra vires as to Maths.

key_quotes.text: A superior of a Math has not only duties to discharge in connection with the endowment but he has a personal interest of a beneficial character which is sanctioned by custom.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines proprietary interest of Mathadhipati under Article 19(1)(f).

key_quotes.text: The 26(b), therefore, a religious denomination or organization enjoys complete autonomy in the matter of deciding as to what rites and ceremonies are essential according to the tenets of the religion they hold.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Scope of Article 26(b) on religious practices.

key_quotes.text: A fee is generally defined to be a charge for a special service rendered to individuals by some governmental agency.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes fee from tax for section 76.
